data.body: You'll have to move `controls = new THREE.FlyControls( dummy );` to your `initialize()` method. When the controls are created they bind themselves mouse/keyboard events and set focus to the input element (in your case that's `window.document`). In order to add the event listeners and set the focus, the DOM must already be loaded.

Thanks for the reply, didn't realize about having to let the DOM load first, so that's good to know.
Moved `var controls = new THREE.FlyControls( dummy );` into `initialiaze()`
(right above`//camera control properties`).

No effect on target! It's game over man, GAME OVER!

Tried a few other things like changing `controls.domElement = viewport;` to `controls.domElement = window.document;`, `controls.domElement = document.getElementById('body');` and even putting the whole script element inside the body, after the 'viewport' div to make sure the DOM is loaded... but none of it works. Did you get it working on your end just by moving the controls constructor?

Couple other things:
`var viewport = document.getElementById('viewport');` changed to `var viewport, controls;` as there is no "viewport" element to get at that point (DOM isn't loaded), moved `viewport = document.getElementById('viewport');` to the initialize method.

Controls require you to tell them when to update. Mouse/keyboard input is saved up for when this update is trigged: `controls.update( delta )` where delta is a number indicating how much of a jump to make. I just use `delta = 1` for simplicity.

[Working demonstration of your code here.](http://jsfiddle.net/chandlerprall/WMuEw/)
